[Exam: Part I 2023] Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the HTT gene. Key concepts:
• Trinucleotide repeat expansions produce toxic gain-of-function proteins; CAG encodes polyglutamine.
• Anticipation: number of repeats often increases in successive generations, especially paternal transmission, correlating with earlier onset.
• Clinical triad: chorea (abnormal involuntary movements), cognitive decline, psychiatric disturbances (depression, irritability).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The HTT gene on chromosome 4p16.3 harbors a CAG repeat: normal ≤26; intermediate 27–35; reduced penetrance 36–39; full penetrance ≥40. Expanded polyglutamine tract induces neuronal dysfunction and apoptosis, predominantly in the striatum and cortex. Walker FO (Lancet 2007) and Ross & Tabrizi (Lancet Neurol 2011) elucidate the pathogenic cascade: mutant huntingtin disrupts transcription, mitochondrial function, and proteostasis. Clinical guidelines (see below) mandate PCR-based CAG sizing for definitive diagnosis and predictive testing.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CTG
• Mutation in DMPK gene causing myotonic dystrophy type 1
• Represents myotonia, cataracts, cardiac conduction defects, not chorea
• Misconception: CTG expansions cause muscle stiffness, not hyperkinetic movement

C. CGG
• Expansion in FMR1 gene causing Fragile X syndrome
• Presents with intellectual disability, macroorchidism, autism features
• Misconception: any trinucleotide repeat implies neurodegeneration; CGG is developmental

D. GAA
• Expansion in FXN gene causing Friedreich’s ataxia
• Leads to spinocerebellar ataxia, sensory neuropathy, cardiomyopathy
• Misconception: GAA can cause falls, but pathology is cerebellar, not choreiform

[Exam: Part II 2019] Wilson’s disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder of copper excretion leading to toxic accumulation in liver, brain and other organs.
• ATP7B mutation impairs biliary copper excretion and incorporation into ceruloplasmin.
• Untreated, patients develop hepatic failure, neuropsychiatric dysfunction and hemolysis.
• Lifelong copper chelation is required; abrupt withdrawal precipitates neurologic deterioration.
In pregnancy, chelation must continue at the lowest effective dose to prevent maternal and fetal complications while minimizing teratogenic risk. (135 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

The primary objective in pregnant patients with Wilson’s disease is to maintain negative copper balance without exposing the fetus to high teratogenic risk. D-Penicillamine has >40 years of safety data in pregnancy:
– A retrospective series of 61 pregnancies on D-penicillamine (average dose 750 mg/day) showed no increase in major congenital malformations; only mild cutis laxa occurred when doses exceeded 1 g/day (Weiss et al., J Hepatol 2002).
– EASL 2012 Guidelines (Level III evidence, Grade C2) recommend continuation of D-penicillamine throughout pregnancy, with dose reduction by 25–50% after the first trimester.
– AASLD 2018 Wilson’s Disease Guidance (expert opinion) similarly endorses ongoing penicillamine at the minimal effective dose, reserving trientine for penicillamine intolerance.
Trientine has fewer teratogenicity reports but limited data; zinc monotherapy is slower and not first-line in active disease. Liver transplantation is reserved for fulminant hepatic failure, not routine management in pregnancy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Trientine
• While an alternative chelator with theoretical lower teratogenicity, it lacks the robust pregnancy safety data of penicillamine.
• Common misconception: “Newer drug = safer in pregnancy.” In reality, limited human data make it second-line.

C. Zinc
• Mechanism is copper absorption blockade, slower onset of action.
• Misconception: “Zinc is non-teratogenic so preferred.” Zinc monotherapy may be insufficient in active disease and is typically adjunctive.

D. Liver transplantation
• Definitive cure for end-stage liver disease but carries high maternal/fetal morbidity and immunosuppression risks.
• Not indicated for stable pregnant patients on medical therapy.

1. Always continue chelation in pregnant Wilson’s patients; abrupt withdrawal risks hepatic/neurologic flare.
2. Reduce D-penicillamine by 25–50% after the first trimester to minimize fetal connective-tissue defects.
3. Monitor copper and ceruloplasmin levels monthly; adjust therapy to clinical and biochemical response.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Discontinuing all chelators out of teratogenic fear—leads to disease flares and fetal risk.
2. Switching stable patients from penicillamine to zinc monotherapy—insufficient for active copper removal.

2. AASLD Practice Guidance on Wilson’s Disease, 2018
– Expert opinion: Maintain lifelong chelation therapy during pregnancy, using the minimal effective dose of D-penicillamine; reserve trientine for penicillamine intolerance.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

D-Penicillamine
• Mechanism: Forms stable 1:1 complexes with copper, excreted in urine.
• Usual adult dose: 750–1,500 mg/day in divided doses; in pregnancy reduce to 500–750 mg/day after week 12.
• Monitor: Complete blood count, urinalysis, liver function, copper levels monthly.
• Adverse: Proteinuria, lupus-like syndrome, cutis laxa in fetus if >1 g/day.

Board Examination Focus

Management of Wilson’s disease in pregnancy is a high-yield topic for both neurology and hepatology sections, frequently tested as single-best-answer questions on chelation choice and dose adjustments. This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Candidates should recognize the primacy of continuing chelation with D-penicillamine at adjusted doses rather than switching to newer agents without sufficient safety data.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Sydenham’s chorea is a major manifestation of acute rheumatic fever, resulting from cross-reactive antibodies targeting basal ganglia neurons following group A streptococcal (GAS) infection.
• Basal ganglia circuits regulate movement; immunologic injury leads to involuntary, irregular choreiform movements.
• Diagnosis of Sydenham’s chorea relies on clinical criteria (Jones criteria) plus evidence of recent GAS exposure, typically via anti-streptolysin O (ASO) or anti-DNase B titers.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Obtaining an ASO titer is the first step to confirm prior GAS infection in suspected Sydenham’s chorea. The 2015 American Heart Association guidelines recommend anti-streptococcal antibody testing (ASO and/or anti-DNase B) in all suspected acute rheumatic fever cases (Level C evidence). An elevated ASO supports a post-streptococcal etiology, which directs long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrence and rheumatic heart disease. While dopamine antagonists (e.g., haloperidol) and corticosteroids can manage symptoms or reduce inflammation, they follow diagnostic confirmation. Brain MRI is typically normal in classical Sydenham’s chorea and does not change management unless atypical features suggest an alternative pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start dopamine antagonists
• Incorrect: Symptomatic treatment reserved after confirming GAS etiology. Misconception: initiating antipsychotics before establishing diagnosis.

C. Immediate corticosteroid therapy
• Incorrect: Reserved for severe or refractory chorea; not the initial diagnostic intervention. Misconception: steroids are universally first-line.

D. Brain MRI
• Incorrect: Imaging is unnecessary in classic Sydenham’s chorea; yields no diagnostic information. Misconception: assuming structural imaging is always indicated for movement disorders.

- Sydenham’s chorea may present weeks to months after pharyngitis; probe for remote sore throat history.
• Always apply the Jones criteria; chorea can be the sole major manifestation of acute rheumatic fever.
• Initiate secondary penicillin prophylaxis once GAS involvement is confirmed by ASO or anti-DNase B titers.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Ordering neuroimaging before serologic confirmation of GAS infection.
• Starting symptomatic therapy without establishing etiology.
• Misdiagnosing chorea as a primary psychiatric or functional disorder in children.

- American Heart Association 2015 (“Prevention of Rheumatic Fever and Diagnosis of Streptococcal Infections”): Recommends ASO and/or anti-DNase B titers in all suspected acute rheumatic fever (Level C).
• ESPID 2021 Consensus on Pediatric Acute Rheumatic Fever: Advises demonstration of recent GAS infection via serology before instituting long-term antibiotic prophylaxis.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a late-onset neurodegenerative disorder seen in carriers of the FMR1 gene premutation (55–200 CGG repeats). Key clinical features include progressive cerebellar ataxia, intention tremor, parkinsonism, and cognitive decline beginning after age 50. Neuroanatomically, FXTAS targets white matter tracts—especially the middle cerebellar peduncles (MCPs)—producing the characteristic “MCP sign” on T2/FLAIR MRI. Pathophysiologically, elevated FMR1 mRNA exerts a toxic gain-of-function, leading to intranuclear inclusions in neurons and astrocytes. While penetrance is higher in males, female carriers can present predominantly with ataxia and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Recognizing the MCP hyperintensity is critical to distinguish FXTAS from other adult-onset ataxias and paraneoplastic or demyelinating processes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

FXTAS diagnostic criteria (Jacquemont et al., Ann Neurol 2003) require:
1. FMR1 premutation (55–200 CGG repeats) on genetic testing.
2. Major clinical signs: intention tremor and/or cerebellar ataxia.
3. Major radiologic sign: symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in the MCPs.

Hall et al. (Neurology 2014) reported the MCP sign in ~60% of FXTAS patients. The American Academy of Neurology (2018) practice guideline for tremor evaluation recommends FMR1 premutation testing in adults with progressive ataxia and MCP hyperintensities (Level B evidence). In contrast, paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration presents subacutely (weeks–months), with diffuse cerebellar cortical atrophy and onconeural antibodies (Graus et al., Lancet Neurol 2021). Multiple sclerosis typically shows periventricular and juxtacortical lesions with CSF oligoclonal bands, not isolated MCP hyperintensities. Spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs) often appear earlier, with family history and pontine “hot cross bun” changes on MRI (Oz et al., Brain 2017). Thus, the constellation here is pathognomonic for FXTAS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Paraneoplastic
• Onset is subacute (weeks–months) with rapid cerebellar decline.
• MRI shows cerebellar cortical atrophy, not isolated MCP hyperintensities.
• Positive anti-Yo, anti-Hu or anti-Tr antibodies.

C. Benign multiple sclerosis
• MS does not begin de novo at age 78.
• Imaging in MS: periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial lesions; Dawson’s fingers.
• CSF: oligoclonal bands and pleocytosis absent here.

D. Spinocerebellar ataxia
• SCAs present earlier (30–50 years) with autosomal dominant pedigree.
• MRI: pontine atrophy and cross-bun sign (especially in SCA2/3), not isolated MCP sign.
• No FMR1 premutation association.

Clinical Pearls

- The “MCP sign” (bilateral middle cerebellar peduncle hyperintensities) is highly specific for FXTAS over other adult-onset ataxias.
• Female FMR1 premutation carriers have lower penetrance and often present with predominant ataxia, less tremor than males.
• Differentiate MCP hyperintensities from the pontine “hot cross bun” sign seen in MSA-C and some SCAs.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing MCP hyperintensities to multiple system atrophy (MSA): MSA-C shows pontine and cerebellar atrophy without symmetric MCP T2 signal.
2. Overlooking FXTAS in females: reduced penetrance leads to underdiagnosis; always consider FMR1 testing in late-onset ataxia with MCP sign regardless of sex.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 Practice Guideline on Tremor Evaluation
– Recommendation: Test for FMR1 premutation in adults >50 with progressive cerebellar ataxia and MCP hyperintensities (Level B evidence).
2. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) 2023 Clinical Guidelines on Adult Ataxias
– Recommendation: Include FMR1 premutation assay in the workup of unexplained late-onset ataxia when MRI reveals MCP signal changes (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The middle cerebellar peduncles carry pontocerebellar fibers essential for motor coordination. In FXTAS, white matter degeneration and intranuclear inclusions disrupt these tracts, leading to ataxia and intention tremor.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded FMR1 mRNA (55–200 CGG repeats) accumulates in the nucleus, sequestering RNA-binding proteins and triggering ubiquitin-positive intranuclear inclusions in neurons and glia. This toxic gain-of-function leads to white matter degeneration predominantly in the MCPs and corpus callosum.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: progressive intention tremor ± cerebellar gait ataxia in a patient >50.
2. MRI brain: look for symmetric MCP hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR.
3. Exclude other causes: CSF for MS/paraneoplastic panels, onconeural Ab testing.
4. Genetic testing: quantify FMR1 CGG repeat number.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2/FLAIR: bilateral, symmetric MCP hyperintensities (“MCP sign”) are seen in ~60% of FXTAS cases.
• Additional findings: diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy; increased signal in splenium of corpus callosum.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No disease-modifying therapy exists for FXTAS. Symptomatic management:
• Tremor: primidone or propranolol (class C evidence).
• Ataxia/gait instability: physical and occupational therapy; balance training.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. FXTAS is frequently tested as a radiographic-clinical correlation—recognition of the MCP sign with genetic confirmation is a high-yield concept on neurology boards.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Tic disorders arise from dysfunction in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical circuits involving the basal ganglia and prefrontal cortex, leading to sudden, stereotyped motor or vocal movements.
DSM-5 classifies tics by duration and type:
• Transient (provisional) tic disorder: single/multiple motor or vocal tics, <12 months.
• Chronic motor or vocal tic disorder: single type only, >12 months.
• Tourette syndrome: ≥2 motor tics + ≥1 vocal tic, present >12 months, onset <18 years.
Stereotypies are rhythmic, prolonged, often seen in younger children or autism, and lack the suppressibility and variability of tics.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tourette syndrome (TS) is defined by the DSM-5 (2013) as multiple motor tics plus at least one vocal tic, with symptom duration exceeding one year and onset before age 18. This patient has both motor (e.g., eye blinking, shoulder shrugging) and vocal (throat clearing, sniffing) tics for 14 months, fitting TS criteria exactly. The American Academy of Neurology’s 2019 practice guideline (Pringsheim et al.) confirms that diagnosis hinges on tic type and duration, not severity. Neurophysiologically, TS is linked to disinhibition within the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia, leading to overflow movements. Epidemiological studies report prevalence of 0.3–0.8% in school-aged children, with a male predominance.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chronic tic disorder
• Incorrect because this requires only motor OR only vocal tics for >12 months.
• Misconception: that “chronic” implies severity rather than absence of combined tics.
• Differentiator: TS mandates both motor and vocal tics.

B. Stereotypes
• Incorrect: stereotypies are rhythmic, prolonged, often in infants or ASD, and not suppressible in the same way.
• Misconception: equating any repetitive movement with tics.
• Differentiator: stereotypies lack the sudden, brief, suppressible nature of tics and absence of vocalizations.

D. Transient tic disorder
• Incorrect because duration here is 14 months (>12 months).
• Misconception: assuming any childhood tic is provisional.
• Differentiator: transient tic disorder requires resolution within one year.

Clinical Pearls

• First-line therapy for TS in children with impairing tics is Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT).
• Common comorbidities include ADHD and OCD; screen routinely as they often drive impairment more than tics.
• Educate families that tic severity often peaks in early adolescence and declines in late teens.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Classifying any tic >6 months as Tourette—must be >12 months.
2. Failing to distinguish vocal from motor tics; chronic tic disorder excludes combined tics.
3. Misidentifying stereotypies (e.g., in autism) as tics—note differences in suppressibility and sensory premonitory urge.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN), 2019 Practice Guideline (Pringsheim et al.):
– Recommendation: Aripiprazole and risperidone have Level A evidence for reducing tic severity in TS.
2. AAN, 2018 Behavioral Therapies Guideline (Piacentini et al.):
– Recommendation: Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) is Level A evidence for children and adults with TS.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a late-onset, hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by involuntary, choreoathetoid movements—classically of the orofacial region—arising after months to years of dopamine-receptor blocking agent exposure. Key concepts:
1. Dopamine D₂‐receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway leads to receptor upregulation and supersensitivity.
2. TD movements are irregular, purposeless, and persist despite cessation of triggers.
3. Differential includes drug-induced parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor), essential tremor (action tremor, postural), and dystonia (sustained muscle contractions).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tardive dyskinesia is directly linked to chronic antipsychotic use, particularly first-generation agents. The Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) is the standard tool for diagnosis and monitoring. The American Academy of Neurology (2018) recommends VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) for TD with Level B evidence. KINECT 3 (JAMA Psychiatry 2017) demonstrated significant reduction in AIMS scores with valbenazine. Pathophysiologically, chronic D₂ blockade induces striatal GABAergic interneuron dysfunction and cholinergic imbalance, producing hyperkinetic movements. By contrast, parkinsonism from antipsychotics presents with bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, and a resting tremor soon after drug initiation; essential tremor yields bilateral postural/action tremors relieved by alcohol; dystonia shows sustained, repetitive muscle contractions early in therapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect: Characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, resting “pill-rolling” tremor, not choreoathetoid movements.
• Misconception: All antipsychotic-related movements are parkinsonian; TD is hyperkinetic.
• Differentiator: Onset of drug-induced parkinsonism is subacute with slowed movements, whereas TD is delayed and hyperkinetic.

C. Essential tremor
• Incorrect: Produces symmetric postural/action tremor of hands/head, improves with alcohol.
• Misconception: Any tremulous movement is ET.
• Differentiator: ET is rhythmic, 4–12 Hz action tremor; TD is arrhythmic choreiform.

D. Dystonia
• Incorrect: Involves sustained, twisting muscle contractions, often acute onset within days of antipsychotic initiation.
• Misconception: All antipsychotic movement disorders are dystonic.
• Differentiator: Dystonia presents with fixed postures; TD is flowing, repetitive, choreiform.

Clinical Pearls

- Perform routine AIMS scoring every 3–6 months in patients on antipsychotics to screen for early TD.
• VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine 40–80 mg daily) are first-line for moderate-to-severe TD.
• Distinguish acute dystonic reactions (treat with benztropine) from delayed-onset TD (requires VMAT2 inhibitors).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all antipsychotic-induced movements to drug-induced parkinsonism, leading to mismanagement with anticholinergics.
2. Overlooking TD because movements can wax and wane; failure to perform regular AIMS assessments delays diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (2018): Practice guideline for pharmacologic treatment of tardive syndromes; recommends valbenazine and deutetrabenazine (Level B).
• APA Schizophrenia Guideline (2021): Advises periodic movement disorder screening and VMAT2 inhibitors for TD (Grade A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

TD implicates dysfunction in the nigrostriatal pathway: chronic D₂ blockade in the striatum causes GABAergic interneuron downregulation and cholinergic interneuron imbalance, releasing involuntary movements via disinhibited thalamocortical circuits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic dopamine receptor blockade → receptor supersensitivity ↑ → altered GABAergic tone ↓ and cholinergic interneuron downregulation → hyperkinetic choreiform movements.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History of antipsychotic exposure ≥3 months.
2. Perform AIMS to quantify involuntary movements.
3. Rule out other causes (thyroid, Wilson’s).
4. Initiate VMAT2 inhibitor if moderate-to-severe.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Routine imaging is normal in TD; functional PET may show striatal dopamine receptor supersensitivity but is not indicated clinically.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Valbenazine: VMAT2 inhibitor, start 40 mg PO daily, may titrate to 80 mg.
• Deutetrabenazine: 6 mg twice daily, titrate by 6 mg weekly to max 48 mg/day.
• Monitor for somnolence, QT prolongation (valbenazine).

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by ATP7B mutations, leading to impaired biliary copper excretion and toxic copper accumulation in liver, brain and cornea. Kayser-Fleischer rings, copper deposits in Descemet’s membrane, are pathognomonic. Neurologic manifestations (parkinsonism, dystonia, ataxia, chorea) stem from basal ganglia copper toxicity and oxidative injury. Primary management requires copper chelation to halt ongoing deposition and mobilize stored copper. D-penicillamine, a thiol chelator, forms a complex with free copper, enhancing urinary excretion. Symptomatic agents (e.g., levodopa, anticholinergics) may provide transient relief but do not modify disease progression. Early chelation correlates with superior neurologic recovery and reduced hepatic sequelae.

Evidence-Based Analysis

D-penicillamine remains first-line chelation therapy. In a seminal randomized trial, Brewer et al. (Ann Neurol. 1987;22(3):360-368) demonstrated neurological improvement in 70% of treated patients at one year. The 2018 AASLD Practice Guidance for Wilson Disease recommends initiating D-penicillamine at 250 mg BID, titrating to 1 g/day (Grade 1A) to achieve 24-hour urinary copper excretion >100 μg (Morgan et al., Hepatology. 2018). For penicillamine intolerance, trientine is endorsed (EASL Clinical Practice Guidelines 2012; Evidence level B). Chelation therapy reduces hepatic inflammation, prevents cirrhosis progression, and ameliorates basal ganglia oxidative injury. Symptomatic drugs (levodopa, anticholinergics, amantadine) do not affect copper homeostasis; thus, they are adjunctive only.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Levodopa
• Incorrect because parkinsonism in Wilson disease is due to copper-induced basal ganglia toxicity, not nigrostriatal dopamine deficiency.
• Misconception: Treating any parkinsonian syndrome with levodopa.
• Differentiator: Does not remove copper or prevent further neurologic injury.

C. Trihexyphenidyl
• Incorrect as it offers only anticholinergic symptomatic relief for dystonia.
• Misconception: All dystonias respond to anticholinergics regardless of etiology.
• Differentiator: Does not chelate copper or alter disease course.

D. Amantadine
• Incorrect because its NMDA-antagonist and weak dopamine-releasing actions do not address copper accumulation.
• Misconception: Amantadine is broadly efficacious in secondary parkinsonism.
• Differentiator: No impact on hepatic or systemic copper levels.

1. Always screen for Kayser-Fleischer rings with slit lamp in unexplained movement disorders.
2. Monitor penicillamine therapy with serial 24-hour urinary copper and complete blood counts (risk of cytopenias, proteinuria).
3. Zinc salts may be added for maintenance once chelation achieves negative copper balance.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating Wilsonian parkinsonism with idiopathic Parkinson’s disease and using levodopa monotherapy without chelation.
2. Initiating only symptomatic treatment (anticholinergics, amantadine) while delaying definitive chelation, leading to irreversible neurologic damage.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases (AASLD) Practice Guidance 2018
• Recommends D-penicillamine or trientine as first-line chelators (Grade 1A).
• Target: 24-hour urinary copper >100 μg on chelation.
2. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2019; CD012123
• Systematic review of chelators vs zinc: Chelators superior for neurologic improvement (Level II evidence).
• Highlights need for RCTs comparing D-penicillamine and trientine directly.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Copper deposition predominantly affects basal ganglia (putamen and globus pallidus), disrupting inhibitory-excitatory balance in motor circuits and manifesting as parkinsonism and dystonia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

ATP7B mutation → impaired hepatic copper excretion → free copper catalyzes reactive oxygen species → lipid peroxidation and neuronal death in basal ganglia, as well as hepatocellular injury.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: neuropsychiatric + KF rings.
2. Serum ceruloplasmin <20 mg/dL.
3. 24-hour urinary copper >100 μg.
4. Liver biopsy copper quantification (>250 μg/g dry weight).
5. ATP7B genetic testing for confirmation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI: T2 hyperintensity in basal ganglia; “face of the giant panda” sign in midbrain tegmentum.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Dosing: Initiate D-penicillamine 250 mg PO BID, increase by 250 mg every 1–2 weeks to 1 g/day. Monitor CBC, urinalysis monthly initially. If intolerant, switch to trientine 250 mg TID.

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Wilson disease treatment frequently appears on neurology and internal medicine boards as a paired vignette requiring identification of Kayser-Fleischer rings and selection of appropriate chelation therapy.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Sydenham chorea is a post-streptococcal autoimmune movement disorder targeting basal ganglia circuits. The caudate nucleus and putamen modulate motor output via direct and indirect pathways; antibody-mediated dysfunction here causes rapid, irregular involuntary movements. It typically arises in school-age children 4–6 weeks after group A Streptococcus pharyngitis and represents a major Jones criterion for acute rheumatic fever. Molecular mimicry—cross-reaction between streptococcal M protein and neuronal antigens—underlies its pathogenesis. Clinicians must integrate rheumatologic features (arthritis, carditis) with choreiform movements to make an early diagnosis and prevent rheumatic heart disease progression.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sydenham chorea fulfills a major criterion in the 2015 American Heart Association Revised Jones Criteria (Class I, Level C). Anti-streptococcal antibodies cross-react with basal ganglia neurons, disrupting dopaminergic-GABAergic transmission (Cunningham MW, 2012). MRI is usually normal; FDG-PET shows transient caudate hypermetabolism. Symptomatic treatment: haloperidol (0.01–0.05 mg/kg/day) or valproate (15 mg/kg/day) yields significant chorea reduction (Cardoso F et al., 2014). Small RCTs demonstrate that corticosteroids (prednisone 2 mg/kg/day tapered over 6 weeks) shorten symptom duration (McCreary MK et al., 2016). Long-term benzathine penicillin G every 4 weeks prevents recurrence and progression of rheumatic carditis (AHA Class I, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. “Is primarily caused by Huntington’s disease”
• Huntington’s is an adult-onset autosomal dominant disorder (CAG repeat expansion in HTT) causing chorea plus progressive cognitive and psychiatric decline. Sydenham chorea occurs in children post-streptococcal infection.

C. “Is characterized by rigidity and bradykinesia”
• Rigidity and bradykinesia define parkinsonism (e.g., Parkinson disease). Chorea features hyperkinetic, irregular, non-rhythmic movements without sustained resistance to passive movement.

D. “Is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nerves”
• Guillain-Barré syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy affect peripheral nerves, causing ascending weakness and sensory loss. Sydenham chorea is a central basal ganglia disorder causing involuntary movements, not peripheral neuropathy.

Clinical Pearls

• Screen for antistreptococcal titers (ASO, anti-DNase B) and perform echocardiography for silent carditis in any child with new-onset chorea.
• First-line symptomatic agents are valproate and haloperidol; consider corticosteroids or IVIG in severe or refractory cases.
• Maintain benzathine penicillin G prophylaxis every 4 weeks for ≥10 years or until age 21 to prevent recurrences and rheumatic heart disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing pediatric chorea to psychogenic causes without investigating for post-streptococcal autoimmunity—always check infection history and ASO titers.
2. Confusing chorea with tics—Sydenham chorea is continuous, non-suppressible, and exacerbates with stress, unlike transient, suppressible tics.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association, 2015 Revised Jones Criteria: Sydenham chorea is a major criterion for acute rheumatic fever diagnosis (Class I, Level C evidence).
• World Heart Federation, 2017 Rheumatic Heart Disease Prophylaxis Guidelines: recommend intramuscular benzathine penicillin G every 4 weeks for secondary prophylaxis in patients with Sydenham chorea (Class I, Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cross-reactive antibodies disrupt the balance between the direct (striatonigral) and indirect (striatopallidal) basal ganglia pathways, causing thalamocortical disinhibition and choreiform movements.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Molecular mimicry between group A streptococcal M protein and neuronal antigens (e.g., lysoganglioside) leads to anti-neuronal antibody production, complement activation, and dysfunction of basal ganglia neurons.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Obtain thorough history of streptococcal infection and rheumatic fever signs
2. Order ASO and anti-DNase B titers
3. Perform echocardiography for valvulitis
4. Neurological exam to document chorea; exclude alternative etiologies

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically unremarkable; SPECT or FDG-PET may show transient hyperactivity in the caudate and putamen correlating with chorea severity.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Haloperidol: initiate 0.01–0.05 mg/kg/day in divided doses; monitor for extrapyramidal side effects.
• Valproate: 15 mg/kg/day; monitor liver function and platelet count.
• Corticosteroids: prednisone 2 mg/kg/day for 2–4 weeks with gradual taper over 6 weeks in severe cases.

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Sydenham chorea (SC) is an autoimmune-mediated movement disorder occurring 4–8 weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. It involves basal ganglia dysfunction due to molecular mimicry between streptococcal antigens and neuronal tissue. Clinically, SC presents in children (mean age 5–15 years) with choreiform movements, hypotonia, emotional lability, and gait disturbances. Differentiating SC from other choreas relies on the temporal relationship to infection, laboratory evidence of recent streptococcal exposure (elevated ASO/anti-DNase B titers), and absence of systemic features seen in alternative diagnoses.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sydenham chorea is recognized as one of the major Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever in the American Heart Association’s 2015 Revised Rheumatic Fever Guidelines (LoE C). The 4–6-week latency period after pharyngitis, elevated anti-streptolysin O titers, and the absence of hepatic, hematologic, or structural brain abnormalities support SC. Kirvan et al. (J Neuroimmunol. 2006) demonstrated anti-basal ganglia autoantibodies in SC patients, confirming its immunopathogenesis. Management is primarily supportive; corticosteroids can shorten symptom duration (Bauer et al., Pediatr Neurol. 2002; LoE B), while valproate or haloperidol may control severe chorea. Long-term penicillin prophylaxis prevents recurrence.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Chorea-acanthocytosis
– Incorrect: Presents in young adults with neurodegeneration, orofacial dystonia, seizures, and peripheral acanthocytes.
– Misconception: All chorea in children is post-infectious.
– Differentiation: SC lacks acanthocytes, seizure activity, and orofacial biting.

C. Wilson’s disease
– Incorrect: Manifests in adolescents/adults with hepatic dysfunction, Kayser-Fleischer rings, psychiatric changes, and dystonia.
– Misconception: Wilson’s can present solely as chorea.
– Differentiation: Normal ceruloplasmin and no liver abnormalities in SC.

D. Essential tremor
– Incorrect: Characterized by bilateral, postural/action tremor of hands/head, improving with alcohol, without choreiform movements.
– Misconception: Any involuntary movement is tremor.
– Differentiation: SC movements are irregular, unpredictable chorea, not rhythmic tremor.

Clinical Pearls

• Sydenham chorea may present with hypotonia (“milkmaid’s grip”) and emotional lability.
• It is often self-limited over 2–6 months, but prophylactic penicillin is essential to prevent rheumatic carditis.
• In severe cases, corticosteroids accelerate resolution; anti-dopaminergic agents manage chorea but carry extrapyramidal risks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling chorea as tremor: chorea is arrhythmic, unpredictable, unlike rhythmic essential tremor.
2. Overlooking rheumatic carditis: always perform echocardiography in suspected SC to rule out subclinical valvulitis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association, 2015 Revised Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever (LoE C): Sydenham chorea is a major manifestation; requires evidence of recent streptococcal infection.
• Pediatric Neurology Society, 2021 Consensus on Pediatric Movement Disorders (LoE B): Recommends corticosteroids for moderate-to-severe SC to reduce chorea duration.

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Sydenham chorea, as a major Jones criterion, is frequently tested in promotion and board exams, often emphasizing the latency period after streptococcal infection and differentiation from metabolic or genetic choreas.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Chronic dopamine D2‐receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway leads to compensatory receptor upregulation and hypersensitivity, manifesting as tardive syndromes.
Key concepts:
1. Basal ganglia circuits—especially the direct and indirect pathways in the dorsal striatum—modulate movement; imbalance causes hyperkinetic or hypokinetic disorders.
2. Acute vs. tardive antipsychotic‐induced movement disorders differ by latency, phenomenology, and reversibility.
3. Orofacial choreoathetoid movements (tongue protrusion, lip smacking) emerging after months to years of neuroleptic exposure are hallmark for tardive dyskinesia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is best explained by chronic D2 blockade inducing postsynaptic receptor supersensitivity in the nigrostriatal pathway. The 2021 APA Practice Guideline for Schizophrenia recommends systematic AIMS screening and use of vesicular monoamine transporter 2 (VMAT2) inhibitors (valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) for moderate–severe TD (Level B evidence). A 2018 AAN guideline update on tardive syndromes rates valbenazine and deutetrabenazine as Level A for symptomatic improvement (Jankovic et al., Neurology 2018). A Cochrane review (2017) demonstrated a mean 40–50% reduction in AIMS scores with VMAT2 inhibitors vs. placebo (high‐quality RCTs). TD movements are typically persistent, often irreversible without treatment, and distinct from acute dystonia, parkinsonism, or neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
– Incorrect because NMS presents acutely with “lead‐pipe” rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability, elevated CK, leukocytosis.
– Misconception: equating any antipsychotic side‐effect with NMS; NMS is an emergency, not isolated orofacial chorea.
– Differentiator: systemic findings and lab abnormalities vs. purely choreiform movements.

C. Acute dystonic reaction
– Incorrect: acute dystonia manifests within days of antipsychotic initiation as sustained, often painful muscle contractions (e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis), not choreoathetoid orofacial movements.
– Misconception: interpreting all involuntary movements as dystonia.
– Differentiator: timing (hours–days), muscle contraction pattern, reversibility with anticholinergics.

D. Parkinsonism
– Incorrect: drug‐induced parkinsonism features bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, postural instability, symmetrical presentation.
– Misconception: labeling any slowed or stiff movement as parkinsonism; fails to note hyperkinetic nature of chorea.
– Differentiator: hypokinetic vs. hyperkinetic phenomenology; absence of bradykinesia in TD.

Clinical Pearls

• Use the Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) every 6–12 months in patients on antipsychotics.
• VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine 40–80 mg daily; deutetrabenazine titrated to 12–48 mg daily) are first‐line pharmacotherapy for TD.
• Reducing or switching antipsychotics may mitigate TD progression—avoid increasing dose in suspected cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over‐diagnosing dystonia when viewing intermittent choreiform movements.
2. Failing to distinguish tardive dyskinesia from spontaneous or hereditary choreas (e.g., Huntington disease) without drug history.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• APA Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Patients With Schizophrenia, 2021:
– Recommendation: Routine AIMS screening; consider VMAT2 inhibitors for moderate–severe TD (Level B).
• AAN Evidence-Based Guideline Update on Tardive Syndromes, 2018:
– Recommendation: Valbenazine and deutetrabenazine are effective for TD symptom reduction (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

TD arises from dysfunction in the nigrostriatal pathway: chronic D2 blockade alters GABAergic output from the striatum to the globus pallidus and substantia nigra, disrupting thalamo‐cortical modulation and producing hyperkinetic movements.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic dopamine antagonism → postsynaptic D2 receptor upregulation and hypersensitivity → aberrant synaptic plasticity, oxidative stress, GABAergic interneuron loss → involuntary choreiform movements.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm history of ≥3 months neuroleptic exposure.
2. Characterize movement type (chorea vs dystonia vs tremor).
3. Exclude other causes (metabolic, genetic).
4. Grade severity with AIMS.
5. Initiate VMAT2 inhibitor if moderate–severe.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Neuroimaging (MRI/CT) is typically normal; used only to exclude other structural or metabolic etiologies in atypical presentations.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line: VMAT2 inhibitors—valbenazine (initial 40 mg QD, increase to 80 mg), deutetrabenazine (titrate from 12 mg to 48 mg divided BID). Monitor for depression, QT prolongation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] - Cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical (CSTC) circuits: Disinhibition of basal ganglia outputs leads to tic generation.
• Dopaminergic hyperactivity in the striatum underlies motor and vocal tics.
• DSM-5 criteria require multiple motor tics and ≥1 vocal tic persisting >12 months with onset <18 years.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tourette syndrome (TS) is defined in DSM-5 (APA, 2013) by the presence of ≥2 motor tics and ≥1 vocal tic for >12 months, with onset before age 18. This patient’s 14-month history of combined tics meets criteria, whereas transient tic disorder is <12 months and chronic motor tic disorder lacks vocal tics. OCD co-occurs in up to 50% of TS cases (Robertson MM et al., 2009). Structural MRI is usually normal, but volumetric studies show reduced caudate correlating with tic severity (Peterson BS et al., 2003). The American Academy of Neurology practice guideline (Pringsheim et al., 2019) recommends Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) first-line and antipsychotics (risperidone, aripiprazole) second-line.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Transient tic disorder
• Incorrect because tics in this disorder resolve within 12 months; here they persist 14 months.
C. Chronic motor tic disorder
• Incorrect because vocal tics are absent in chronic motor tic disorder; this patient has vocal tics.
D. Obsessive-compulsive disorder
• OCD is a common comorbidity but does not explain the presence of motor and vocal tics.

Clinical Pearls

- Always screen for ADHD and OCD in TS; comorbidities alter management strategy.
• CBIT (including habit reversal training) is first-line (Level A evidence, Piacentini et al., 2010).
• Low-dose risperidone (0.25–3 mg/day) or aripiprazole (2.5–10 mg/day) effectively reduce tic severity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling a >12-month tic disorder as “transient”—duration is the key differentiator.
2. Overlooking vocal tics and thus misdiagnosing chronic motor tic disorder.
3. Attributing all repetitive behaviors to OCD rather than recognizing distinct tic phenomenology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (Pringsheim et al., 2019): CBIT first-line; antipsychotics second-line (Level A).
• European Society for the Study of Tourette Syndrome (Capriotti et al., 2021): Recommends deep brain stimulation for treatment-refractory TS (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

TS involves hyperactivity in the striatum (caudate nucleus, putamen) with insufficient prefrontal cortical inhibition, disrupting CSTC loops.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Excess dopaminergic transmission in basal ganglia lowers the threshold for unwanted motor patterns; GABAergic interneuron deficits further reduce inhibitory control.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Elicit detailed tic history: onset, type, frequency.
2. Apply DSM-5 criteria: ≥2 motor + ≥1 vocal tics >12 months.
3. Exclude secondary causes (e.g., PANDAS, medications).
4. Assess for ADHD, OCD, anxiety.
5. Initiate CBIT; consider pharmacotherapy if severe.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Risperidone: start 0.25 mg BID, titrate to 1–3 mg/day.
• Aripiprazole: 2.5–10 mg/day.
• Monitor weight, metabolic profile, and extrapyramidal symptoms.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] The basal ganglia (caudate, putamen, subthalamic nucleus) modulate voluntary motor activity by inhibiting unwanted movements. Sydenham chorea is an autoimmune reaction after group A streptococcal pharyngitis, mediated by molecular mimicry targeting basal ganglia neurons. Symptoms arise 2–6 weeks post-infection and manifest as rapid, irregular, non‐purposeful movements that worsen with stress and disappear during sleep. It is one of the major Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever. In contrast, Huntington disease presents in adults with progressive chorea plus cognitive decline; Tourette syndrome consists of suppressible, stereotyped tics; and Wilson disease features tremor, dystonia, and hepatic signs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Sydenham chorea fits this case: a 2-week latent period after presumed streptococcal URI, pediatric onset, and choreiform movements. The 2015 American Heart Association revision of the Jones Criteria recognizes isolated chorea as a major criterion for acute rheumatic fever (Class IIa, Level C)1. Autoantibodies against streptococcal M protein cross‐react with basal ganglia antigens, causing neuronal dysfunction2. MRI is often normal or may show subtle basal ganglia T2 hyperintensities. Management includes penicillin prophylaxis and symptomatic therapy with valproic acid (10–15 mg/kg/day) or haloperidol (0.01–0.1 mg/kg/day), both shown to reduce chorea severity and duration3,4.

1. Gewitz MH et al. Circulation. 2015;131(20):1806–1818.
2. Dale RC et al. Brain. 2005;128(Pt 2):413–424.
3. AHA 2015 Jones Criteria update.
4. Oliveira GH et al. J Child Neurol. 2022;37(7):1304–1310.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Huntington disease
• Onset in 30–50 years with autosomal dominant CAG expansion and progressive dementia.
• Misconception: pediatric chorea implies Huntington’s.
• Differentiator: genetic testing confirms CAG repeat; juvenile form causes rigidity/bradykinesia.

C. Tourette syndrome
• Characterized by brief, suppressible motor/vocal tics with premonitory urges.
• Misconception: tics are random hyperkinetic movements.
• Differentiator: tics are stereotyped, wax and wane, and associated with OCD/ADHD.

D. Wilson disease
• Copper accumulation causes tremor, dystonia, hepatic dysfunction, and Kayser–Fleischer rings.
• Misconception: youth movement disorders equal Wilson’s.
• Differentiator: low ceruloplasmin, elevated urinary copper, liver enzyme abnormalities.

Clinical Pearls

- Sydenham chorea can occur as an isolated major Jones criterion; always perform echocardiography to detect silent carditis.
• Long‐term benzathine penicillin G (every 4 weeks) prevents recurrences and rheumatic heart disease.
• Valproic acid is preferred for symptomatic relief due to fewer extrapyramidal side effects compared to neuroleptics.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing suppressible tics (Tourette) with chorea: chorea is nonrhythmic, non-stereotyped, and lacks premonitory urges.
• Neglecting the latent period: chorea may present weeks post–streptococcal infection without concurrent pharyngitis.
• Omitting cardiac evaluation: silent carditis occurs in up to 50% of Sydenham chorea cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

Recommendation: Isolated Sydenham chorea qualifies as a major criterion (Class IIa, Level C).
2. Oliveira GH et al. Valproate vs Haloperidol in Sydenham Chorea: A Randomized Controlled Trial. J Child Neurol. 2022;37(7):1304–1310.
Finding: Valproic acid (15 mg/kg/day) led to faster symptom resolution and fewer adverse effects than haloperidol (0.05 mg/kg/day) (Level I evidence).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Vascular parkinsonism arises from cumulative ischemic lesions in basal ganglia and subcortical white matter, most often due to small‐vessel (lacunar) infarcts. Key concepts:
1. Pathophysiology: Ischemic injury to striato-pallidal pathways (lenticulostriate artery territory) produces bradykinesia and gait disturbance.
2. Clinical features: Symmetrical, lower‐body–predominant parkinsonism with early postural instability and falls; often frontal gait (“marche à petits pas”).
3. Management principle: Unlike idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (PD), vascular parkinsonism has poor levodopa responsiveness; primary therapy is risk‐factor modification, notably blood‐pressure control to prevent further ischemic damage.
(Word count: 103)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hypertension is the strongest modifiable risk factor for small‐vessel cerebrovascular disease leading to vascular parkinsonism. The Perindopril Protection Against Recurrent Stroke Study (PROGRESS, 2001) demonstrated a 28% relative risk reduction in recurrent stroke with blood‐pressure–lowering therapy, which by extension limits further basal ganglia infarction. The AHA/ASA 2021 secondary stroke prevention guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend systolic BP <130 mmHg in patients with prior lacunar strokes. In contrast, multiple series (e.g., Zijlmans et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2019) show <10% of vascular parkinsonism cases respond to levodopa. Surgical interventions (e.g., deep brain stimulation) are ineffective because the underlying pathology is diffuse ischemic rather than focal dopaminergic neuron loss. Thus, controlling hypertension is the cornerstone of management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Start L-Dopa therapy
• Incorrect because vascular parkinsonism demonstrates poor dopaminergic responsiveness in >90% of cases.
• Misconception: equating all parkinsonian syndromes with idiopathic PD.
• Differentiation: In idiopathic PD, >60% improvement with levodopa; in vascular cases, minimal and transient benefit.

C. Refer for surgery
• Surgical options (e.g., DBS) target nigrostriatal degeneration, not multifocal ischemic lesions.
• Misconception: attributing benefit of neurosurgical interventions in all parkinsonian disorders.
• Differentiation: Vascular parkinsonism pathology is patchy white-matter and basal ganglia infarction, unsuitable for focal neuromodulation.

D. No intervention
• Allowing uncontrolled hypertension leads to progression of small-vessel disease and worsening parkinsonism.
• Misconception: believing vascular parkinsonism is benign or static.
• Differentiation: Active risk‐factor control can prevent new ischemic insults and slow clinical deterioration.

Clinical Pearls

1. “Lower‐body parkinsonism” with predominant gait difficulty and falls in an elderly hypertensive patient strongly suggests vascular etiology.
2. MRI showing periventricular white-matter hyperintensities and basal ganglia lacunes supports the diagnosis.
3. Vascular parkinsonism often coexists with gait apraxia and executive dysfunction; treat vascular risk factors to prevent progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating vascular parkinsonism exactly like idiopathic PD with escalating levodopa doses despite poor response.
2. Overlooking stroke‐prevention measures (blood‐pressure control, antiplatelet therapy) in patients with progressive parkinsonism and vascular risk factors.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• PROGRESS Trial (Perindopril Protection Against Recurrent Stroke Study, Lancet 2001): Perindopril ± indapamide reduced stroke recurrence by 28% (p<0.0001) in patients with prior cerebrovascular events.
• AHA/ASA 2021 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Class I, Level A recommendation to maintain systolic BP <130 mmHg in patients with lacunar infarction to reduce recurrence and secondary neurological sequelae.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Tic disorders (e.g., Tourette syndrome) involve disinhibition in cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical loops, with dopaminergic hyperactivity in the basal ganglia leading to involuntary movements/vocalizations. ADHD stems from dysregulation of fronto-striatal circuits, with deficits in prefrontal cortex dopamine and norepinephrine causing inattention and hyperactivity. Effective pharmacotherapy must improve ADHD symptoms without exacerbating tics. Stimulants (methylphenidate) boost dopamine broadly—including in the striatum—and can worsen tics. Atomoxetine, a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, enhances prefrontal signaling with minimal striatal dopamine increase, improving ADHD while neutral or beneficial for tic severity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Atomoxetine’s mechanism—blocking presynaptic norepinephrine transporters—augments prefrontal cortical control over attention and impulse regulation without substantially increasing striatal dopamine. A randomized, placebo-controlled trial (Newcorn et al., 2020) in children with ADHD plus tics demonstrated significant ADHD symptom reduction (ADHD-RS IV score ↓ by 12 points, p<0.001) and no worsening of tic severity. The American Academy of Neurology 2019 guideline on tic disorders recommends nonstimulant ADHD agents (atomoxetine or α2-agonists) as first-line in comorbid cases (Level B). The UK NICE CG72 (2018) similarly endorses atomoxetine when tics coexist. These data underpin atomoxetine’s status as the preferred agent for dual management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Methylphenidate
• Although a first-line ADHD stimulant, it increases synaptic dopamine in both prefrontal cortex and striatum, potentially aggravating tics. The misconception is that all ADHD medications are interchangeable; stimulants carry a tic-worsening risk absent with atomoxetine.

C. Haloperidol
• A D2 antagonist effective for severe tics but offers no ADHD benefit. Its side effects (extrapyramidal symptoms, sedation) limit use in ADHD management. Misconception: antipsychotics can treat hyperactivity/inattention.

D. Valproic acid
• A GABAergic anticonvulsant/mood stabilizer with no proven efficacy in core ADHD symptoms or tic suppression. The error is extending mood-stabilizer indications to ADHD-tic comorbidity without supportive data.

Clinical Pearls

- Atomoxetine is particularly useful when tics predate or co-occur with ADHD; start at 0.5 mg/kg/day and titrate to 1.2 mg/kg/day.
• α2-agonists (guanfacine, clonidine) also target both conditions and may be used if atomoxetine is ineffective or poorly tolerated.
• Many children tolerate stimulants without tic worsening, but baseline tic severity should guide risk–benefit decisions.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all stimulants will inevitably worsen tics—up to 50% of children do not experience tic exacerbation on methylphenidate.
2. Prescribing antipsychotics like haloperidol for ADHD symptoms—these lack efficacy for inattention/hyperactivity and carry significant side effects.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (2019). Practice guideline: Pharmacologic treatment of tic disorders. Recommends atomoxetine or α2-agonists for ADHD with tics (Level B).
• NICE Clinical Guideline CG72 (2018, updated 2020). Urges atomoxetine or extended-release guanfacine when ADHD coexists with tics (strong recommendation).
• Newcorn et al., Journal of Child and Adolescent Psychopharmacology 2020. RCT demonstrating atomoxetine’s dual efficacy in ADHD symptom reduction (p<0.001) and tic stability.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Tic generation implicates sensorimotor loops of the basal ganglia (putamen → globus pallidus → thalamus → cortex). ADHD deficits localize to dorsolateral prefrontal cortex-striatal circuits modulated by NE and dopamine.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Tics reflect overactive dopaminergic transmission in nigrostriatal pathways. ADHD arises from underactivity of catecholaminergic signaling in mesocortical and frontostriatal tracts, leading to executive dysfunction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Atomoxetine
• Mechanism: selective NE reuptake inhibitor
• Dosing: start 0.5 mg/kg/day, increase weekly to 1.2 mg/kg/day (max 100 mg/day)
• Metabolism: CYP2D6 substrate—dose adjustment in poor metabolizers

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sydenham chorea is an autoimmune sequela of group A streptococcal (GAS) infection targeting basal ganglia neurons. Key points:
• Basal ganglia circuits: Antibody-mediated dysfunction of the caudate and putamen disrupts direct/indirect motor pathways, producing choreiform movements.
• Antibody kinetics: Anti-DNase B rises later and remains elevated longer (6–8 months) than ASO (3–6 months), making it ideal for detecting remote GAS infection.
• Revised Jones criteria: In late presentations of rheumatic fever, serologic proof of prior GAS (via anti-DNase B) is essential when throat cultures and ASO may be negative.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anti-DNase B antibody is positive in ~90–95% of Sydenham chorea cases versus ASO in ~50–60%, because chorea typically appears weeks to months after pharyngitis when ASO titers have often normalized. The 2015 AHA rheumatic fever guidelines recommend combined serology but highlight anti-DNase B for late manifestations (Class I, Level B). Johnson et al. (2021) corroborated these findings in a prospective cohort (n=100), demonstrating significantly higher sensitivity for anti-DNase B (92% vs. 56%, p<0.01).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. ASO titer
• ASO peaks at 3–5 weeks and declines by 3–6 months; chorea often presents later, yielding false negatives.
• Misconception: Equating ASO persistence with anti-DNase B.
C. ESR
• A non-specific acute phase reactant; may be normal in isolated chorea without active carditis.
• Mistaken for a diagnostic marker of prior GAS infection.
D. ANA
• Marker of systemic lupus erythematosus and other connective tissue diseases; unrelated to post-streptococcal autoimmunity.
• Reflects confusion between rheumatic and collagen-vascular chorea.

Clinical Pearls

1. In isolated chorea without overt carditis, anti-DNase B is the serologic test of choice for confirming prior GAS infection.
2. Sydenham chorea may be the only major Jones criterion; prompt serology enables early prophylaxis.
3. Benzathine penicillin every 3–4 weeks prevents recurrence and further neurological injury.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on ASO titers in late rheumatic fever yields false negatives.
2. Ordering ANA for pediatric chorea without clinical or laboratory evidence of lupus misdirects treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association (AHA) 2015 Scientific Statement on Rheumatic Fever
• Recommends combined ASO and anti-DNase B testing in late rheumatic fever; anti-DNase B preferred for chorea (Class I, Level B).
2. Johnson et al., Journal of Pediatric Infectious Diseases, 2021
• Prospective study (n=100): anti-DNase B sensitivity 92% vs. ASO 56% in Sydenham chorea (p<0.01), validating guideline emphasis.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Autoimmune targeting of caudate and putamen neurons perturbs dopaminergic/GABAergic balance in basal ganglia motor circuits, leading to choreiform hyperkinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Molecular mimicry between streptococcal antigens (e.g., N-acetyl-β-D-glucosamine) and neuronal antigens triggers cross-reactive antibodies that bind basal ganglia epitopes, activating complement and microglia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify choreiform movements in a child/adolescent.
2. Exclude alternate etiologies (e.g., Wilson disease, SLE).
3. Apply revised Jones criteria; obtain anti-DNase B and ASO titers.
4. Confirm GAS etiology and initiate long-term penicillin prophylaxis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically normal; rare T2 hyperintensities in basal ganglia may reflect inflammation but are non-specific.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First-line symptomatic agents include valproic acid or haloperidol; severe or refractory cases may benefit from corticosteroids or IVIG; maintain benzathine penicillin prophylaxis.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Tardive dyskinesia (TD) arises after months to years of dopamine-receptor antagonist exposure, most commonly antipsychotics. Core concepts:
• Nigrostriatal pathway: chronic D2 blockade in the striatum leads to receptor supersensitivity and involuntary choreiform movements.
• Hyperkinetic vs. hypokinetic syndromes: TD produces chorea, buccolingual movements, distinct from the rigidity and bradykinesia of parkinsonism.
• Clinical recognition: movements often persist or worsen after drug withdrawal; use the Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale (AIMS) for diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Tardive dyskinesia is the prototypical antipsychotic-induced hyperkinetic disorder. The DSM-5 defines TD as involuntary athetoid or choreiform movements developing after neuroleptic exposure. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guideline (level B evidence) endorses VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) as first-line therapy. The KINECT 3 trial (N Engl J Med 2017) demonstrated significant AIMS score reduction with valbenazine vs. placebo (mean change −3.2 vs. −1.4; p<0.001). Diagnosis hinges on history of antipsychotic use, characteristic orofacial dyskinesias, and exclusion of other movement disorders.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect: Parkinsonism features bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, postural instability.
• Misconception: antipsychotic-induced parkinsonism can mimic idiopathic PD, but lacks progressive dopaminergic neuron loss and shows symmetric onset.
• Differentiator: PD tremor is “pill-rolling,” improves with dopaminergic meds; TD movements are choreiform and persist despite discontinuation.

C. Essential tremor
• Incorrect: ET is an action/postural tremor of hands, head, voice; no chorea or buccolingual movements.
• Misconception: any psych-med patient tremor is ET; ET has strong familial pattern and responds to propranolol.
• Differentiator: ET is rhythmic at 4–12 Hz with improvement at rest, unlike irregular TD movements.

D. Dystonia
• Incorrect: dystonia causes sustained muscle contractions, twisting postures, often focal (e.g., torticollis).
• Misconception: any antipsychotic-related movement is dystonia; acute dystonic reactions occur early in treatment, not after long-term.
• Differentiator: dystonic contractions are sustained and intermittent, not the choreoathetoid, repetitive nature of TD.

- Monitor all patients on antipsychotics with AIMS every 6 months.
• VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine 40–80 mg daily; deutetrabenazine 6–12 mg BID) are first-line for moderate-severe TD.
• Early recognition and dose reduction/switch to atypical antipsychotic can limit progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing acute dystonic reactions (hours-days after medication) with TD (months-years).
2. Mislabeling antipsychotic-induced parkinsonism as idiopathic PD; look for symmetry and medication history.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AAN Practice Guideline “Treatment of Tardive Dyskinesia” (2018): VMAT2 inhibitors recommended (Level B).
• American Psychiatric Association Schizophrenia Guideline (2020): routine TD screening; use valbenazine or deutetrabenazine when AIMS ≥3 (Expert consensus).
• KINECT 3 Trial (2017): valbenazine 80 mg led to mean AIMS reduction −9.2 vs. −3.6 placebo at week 6 (p<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Chronic D2 antagonist exposure causes striatal dopaminergic supersensitivity. The direct (striatonigral) and indirect (striatopallidal) pathways become dysregulated, producing hyperkinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Prolonged D2 receptor blockade → upregulation and hypersensitivity → increased dopamine turnover and free-radical damage → choreiform movements.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed medication history (duration, dose, type).
2. Neurological exam with AIMS.
3. Exclude other causes (metabolic, genetic).
4. Grade severity and decide on VMAT2 inhibitor therapy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Valbenazine: selective VMAT2 inhibitor; start 40 mg daily, titrate to 80 mg.
• Deutetrabenazine: start 6 mg BID, increase by 6 mg weekly (max 48 mg/day).
• Monitor for depression, parkinsonism, QT prolongation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] • The subthalamic nucleus (STN) is a pivotal node in the indirect basal ganglia pathway: it sends excitatory glutamatergic projections to the globus pallidus interna (GPi).
• Lesion of the contralateral STN (often a lacunar infarct) reduces GPi inhibitory output to the thalamus, producing hyperkinetic movements (hemiballismus/hemichorea).
• Hemiballismus presents acutely with flinging, high-amplitude movements of the proximal limbs and often improves spontaneously as edema resolves.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer, B. Sub-thalamic, corresponds to infarction of the subthalamic nucleus, the classic neuroanatomical substrate for acute hemiballismus. In a landmark case series by Kim JS et al. (Stroke. 2001;32(7):1238–1242), 21 of 23 patients with unilateral hemiballismus had diffusion-weighted MRI (DWI) evidence of a contralateral STN lesion. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 guidelines recommend urgent MRI-DWI in stroke-like presentations when CT is non-diagnostic (Class I; Level of Evidence A), given its >90% sensitivity for small deep infarcts. Subcortical infarcts in the pons, midbrain, or medulla yield distinct clinical syndromes (e.g., cranial nerve deficits, ocular motor signs, bulbar palsies) rather than pure hyperkinetic movements.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Midbrain
– A midbrain infarct typically produces oculomotor deficits (e.g., vertical gaze palsy), contralateral ataxia (Red nucleus), or parkinsonian features (substantia nigra).
– Misconception: attributing any basal ganglia–adjacent lesion to hemiballismus.
– Differentiator: midbrain lesions spare the indirect pathway node (STN).

C. Pons
– Pontine strokes manifest with contralateral hemiparesis, facial weakness, ataxia, or “crossed” syndromes (e.g., Millard-Gubler) rather than choreiform movements.
– Misconception: deep brainstem lesions universally cause movement disorders.
– Differentiator: pons lacks direct involvement in basal ganglia motor modulation.

D. Medulla
– Medullary infarcts cause bulbar signs (dysphagia, dysphonia), Horner syndrome, or contralateral body sensory loss (e.g., Wallenberg syndrome).
– Misconception: small vessel strokes everywhere can cause hemiballismus.
– Differentiator: medulla has no role in the indirect basal ganglia circuitry.

Clinical Pearls

• Hemiballismus is most often caused by a small lacunar infarct in the contralateral subthalamic nucleus.
• CT may be normal in the acute phase; MRI-DWI within hours is essential for diagnosis.
• Symptoms often improve over days to weeks as peri-infarct edema subsides; pharmacotherapy (e.g., haloperidol) is reserved for severe or persistent cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming large cortical lesions cause hemiballismus—small STN infarcts are the classic etiology.
2. Relying solely on CT to rule out stroke in movement disorders—CT sensitivity for lacunar STN infarcts is <30%.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2018 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke:
– Recommendation: Obtain MRI with DWI in patients with suspected stroke and normal CT (Class I; Level of Evidence A).
• Wardlaw JM et al., “Imaging in Stroke: Current and Emerging Techniques,” Lancet Neurol. 2017;16(6):361–376:
– Meta-analysis demonstrated DWI sensitivity of >90% vs ≤30% for CT in detecting lacunar infarcts.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The STN lies ventral to the thalamus at the diencephalic–mesencephalic junction. It receives cortical input via the hyperdirect pathway and projects excitatory fibers to the GPi, modulating thalamocortical output. Lesioning the STN disinhibits thalamic nuclei, causing hyperkinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of STN excitatory drive reduces GPi-mediated GABAergic inhibition of the ventrolateral thalamus, leading to excessive thalamocortical activation and involuntary, high-amplitude proximal limb movements characteristic of hemiballismus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical recognition of acute hemiballismus/hemichorea.
2. Non-contrast CT to exclude hemorrhage (often normal in lacunar strokes).
3. MRI stroke protocol with DWI, FLAIR, and SWI to identify small deep infarcts—focus on STN region.
4. Vascular risk factor management and symptomatic therapy if movements are disabling.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• DWI is most sensitive for acute ischemia in deep structures within minutes of onset.
• STN infarcts appear as 5–10 mm hyperintense foci on axial DWI, often missed on CT or conventional T2.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) arise from dopamine D2 receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway by antipsychotics. Akathisia presents as an inner sense of restlessness and a compelling need to move, typically days to weeks after starting or increasing antipsychotic dose. Dystonia manifests as sustained, often painful muscle contractions with abnormal postures; chorea features irregular, dance-like movements without subjective restlessness; and tics are brief, suppressible, stereotyped movements or vocalizations preceded by a premonitory urge. Distinguishing these syndromes by phenomenology and timing of onset is critical for targeted treatment in patients with schizophrenia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Akathisia is a medication-induced movement disorder defined in DSM-5. Pathophysiologically, chronic D2 blockade in the striatum disrupts dopaminergic modulation, creating a cholinergic-dopaminergic imbalance that produces restlessness. A meta-analysis by Leucht et al. (2011) showed β-blockers (especially propranolol) reduce akathisia severity by ~50% (p<0.01). The 2022 NICE NG222 guideline (Level I evidence) recommends propranolol 10 mg TID, titrating to effect. If symptoms persist, benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam 0.5–1 mg BID) or switching to a low-potency/atypical antipsychotic (e.g., quetiapine) per WFSBP 2020 guidelines is advised. Prompt recognition and management improve adherence and reduce relapse risk in schizophrenia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chorea
– Arises from striatal lesions (e.g., Huntington disease, Sydenham chorea) causing rapid, irregular, flowing movements without subjective restlessness.
– Misconception: any involuntary movement in an antipsychotic patient is chorea.
– Differentiator: chorea does not respond to β-blockers and lacks an “inner restlessness.”

B. Tics
– Neurodevelopmental; brief, suppressible, stereotyped movements/vocalizations with a premonitory urge.
– Misconception: pacing in akathisia is a tic.
– Differentiator: tics are localized and suppressible; akathisia involves non-focal restlessness.

D. Dystonia
– Presents within hours–days of antipsychotic initiation as sustained, painful muscle contractions and abnormal postures.
– Misconception: all antipsychotic EPS are akathisia.
– Differentiator: dystonia has fixed postures and treats with anticholinergics (e.g., benztropine), not β-blockers.

• Propranolol is first-line; start at 10 mg TID and titrate up to 120 mg/day as needed.
• Switching to low-potency or atypical antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine) can mitigate persistent akathisia.

1. Treating akathisia solely with benzodiazepines, overlooking β-blockers.
2. Misdiagnosing early dystonia as akathisia and delaying anticholinergic therapy.

2. CANMAT & ISBD 2016 Guidelines for Schizophrenia: Endorse β-blockers and benzodiazepines (Level B evidence); advise dose reduction or antipsychotic switch for refractory akathisia.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Dopamine D₂-receptor antagonism in the nigrostriatal pathway reduces inhibitory control over striatal cholinergic interneurons, precipitating an acute imbalance between the direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia circuits.
• Acute dystonic reactions manifest as sustained, often painful muscle contractions—commonly of the oculoglossal, neck, or limb muscles—within hours to days of antipsychotic initiation or dose escalation.
• Tardive dyskinesia appears after months of therapy and is characterized by choreoathetoid (“worm-like”) movements, predominantly involving the bucco-lingual-masticatory apparatus.
• Neuroleptic malignant syndrome and drug-induced parkinsonism have distinct systemic and motor features that differentiate them from isolated dystonic spasms.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acute dystonic reactions typically develop within 24–96 hours of starting or increasing the dose of a dopamine antagonist, with reported incidence up to 25% in patients on high-potency typical antipsychotics (Caroff & Miller, 2015). The American Psychiatric Association’s 2020 Schizophrenia Treatment Guideline recommends intramuscular benztropine 1–2 mg or diphenhydramine 25–50 mg for immediate symptom relief (Level C evidence). Mechanistically, D₂ blockade in the striatum disinhibits cholinergic interneurons, leading to excessive acetylcholine release and sustained muscle contraction. By contrast, tardive dyskinesia is a delayed phenomenon (months to years) involving up-regulation and supersensitivity of postsynaptic D₂ receptors, producing choreiform, repetitive movements rather than sustained dystonic postures. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome features hyperthermia, autonomic instability, “lead-pipe” rigidity, and elevated creatine kinase, while drug-induced parkinsonism presents with bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, and resting tremor.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Tardive Dyskinesia
• Onset: After months to years of antipsychotic therapy.
• Movement: Choreoathetoid, rhythmic, non-sustained.
• Misconception: Any orofacial movement equals tardive dyskinesia—timing and movement quality differentiate.

C. Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome
• Systemic: Fever, autonomic lability, mental status changes, severe “lead-pipe” rigidity, marked CK elevation.
• Misconception: All drug-induced rigidities are NMS—absence of fever and autonomic signs rules it out.

D. Parkinsonism
• Features: Bradykinesia, masked facies, cogwheel rigidity, resting tremor; typically develops over weeks.
• Misconception: Rigidity = dystonia—parkinsonian rigidity is uniform and non-sustained, unlike painful dystonic spasms.

Clinical Pearls

- High-potency typical antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) and young male patients are at greatest risk for acute dystonia.
• Prophylactic benztropine (1–2 mg orally daily) during the first week of high-dose antipsychotic therapy can reduce incidence by up to 50% (APA 2020).
• Acute dystonia is a medical emergency: untreated laryngopharyngeal involvement can compromise airway patency.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misclassifying dystonia as tardive dyskinesia due to orofacial localization, ignoring time course and movement quality.
2. Attributing painful sustained contractions to parkinsonism, rather than recognizing the characteristic cogwheel rigidity without dystonic posturing.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- APA Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Patients with Schizophrenia, 2020: Recommends intramuscular anticholinergics (benztropine 1–2 mg IM or diphenhydramine 25–50 mg IM) for acute dystonia (Level C).
• NICE Guideline NG222 (Psychosis and Schizophrenia in Adults, 2021): Advises routine assessment and prophylaxis for extrapyramidal side effects when prescribing high-potency antipsychotics; recommends valbenazine or deutetrabenazine only for tardive syndromes (Level 1 evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Acute dystonic reactions implicate the nigrostriatal pathway: loss of D₂-mediated inhibition of striatal cholinergic interneurons produces excessive acetylcholine release, resulting in overactivation of the direct striatopallidal circuit and involuntary muscle contractions.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. D₂ blockade ↓ inhibitory tone on cholinergic interneurons.
2. Cholinergic overdrive → sustained muscle fiber depolarization.
3. Imbalance between the direct (facilitation) and indirect (inhibition) basal ganglia loops manifests as dystonia rather than chorea.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Assess onset relative to antipsychotic initiation/escalation.
2. Characterize movement: sustained (dystonia) vs choreiform (dyskinesia) vs tremor/rigidity.
3. Evaluate for systemic signs (fever, autonomic changes).
4. Administer test dose of IM benztropine or diphenhydramine—rapid resolution confirms acute dystonia.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Benztropine 1–2 mg IM or diphenhydramine 25–50 mg IM, repeat PRN.
• Prophylaxis: Oral benztropine 1–2 mg daily for the first week of high-potency antipsychotic therapy.
• Avoid dopamine agonists in schizophrenia; adjust antipsychotic dose after stabilization.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Parkinson’s disease (PD) is defined by nigrostriatal dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra pars compacta, causing classic motor signs. Non-motor features—visual hallucinations and dementia—stem from cortical Lewy body deposition, mesolimbic dopaminergic hyperactivity, and basal forebrain cholinergic deficits. Psychosis in PD requires agents that antagonize 5-HT2A or D2 receptors without exacerbating parkinsonism. Cognitive decline in Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD) reflects cholinergic loss, treatable with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Balancing these pathways guides targeted therapy: antipsychotics for hallucinations and cholinesterase inhibitors for memory.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Clozapine is supported by Level A evidence in the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) evidence-based review (Seppi et al., 2011; updated 2017) for PD psychosis. Two double-blind RCTs (Aarsland et al., 2005; Ondo et al., 2011) demonstrated a 60–80% reduction in hallucination frequency over 6–8 weeks without motor deterioration (D2 occupancy < 60%; potent 5-HT2A antagonism). Rivastigmine (Emre et al., 2004) improved MMSE by ~2 points over 24 weeks (Level B evidence) and mildly reduced Neuropsychiatric Inventory hallucination scores, but lacks primary antipsychotic efficacy. Levodopa intensification aggravates mesolimbic dopamine–mediated psychosis. Amantadine’s NMDA antagonism may precipitate or worsen hallucinations. Therefore, in combined PDP psychosis and dementia, clozapine is the most evidence-based choice.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Rivastigmine
– Targets cholinergic deficits in PDD; improves cognition but has minimal direct antipsychotic effect.
– Misconception: assuming cognitive enhancers resolve psychotic symptoms.
– Does not antagonize mesolimbic dopamine overactivity that underlies hallucinations.

C. Levodopa
– Dopamine precursor for motor symptom relief.
– Worsens psychosis by increasing mesolimbic dopamine.
– Common error: conflating motor improvement with non-motor symptom control.

D. Amantadine
– NMDA receptor antagonist used for levodopa-induced dyskinesias.
– Can provoke or exacerbate hallucinations via anticholinergic side effects.
– Mistakenly believed to have broad neuropsychiatric benefits, but contraindicated in active psychosis.

– Initiate clozapine at 12.5 mg nightly and titrate to 25–50 mg/day; monitor CBC weekly for 6 months, then biweekly.
– Pimavanserin, a 5-HT2A inverse agonist, is an FDA-approved alternative for PDP without motor worsening.
– Always attempt reduction of dopaminergic therapy before adding antipsychotics in PD psychosis.

1. Prescribing risperidone or haloperidol for PDP—high D2 blockade worsens parkinsonism.
2. Assuming cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., rivastigmine) sufficiently treat visual hallucinations.

– Movement Disorder Society Task Force on PDP (Seppi et al., 2011; updated 2017):
• Clozapine – Level A recommendation for PD psychosis.
• Rivastigmine – Level B for PDD cognition; minimal psychosis benefit.
– NICE Guideline NG72 (2017, updated 2022):
• First reduce dopaminergic meds; then consider clozapine in specialist centers.
• Use rivastigmine transdermal for PDD cognitive symptoms (Evidence level 1+).
– Pimavanserin Phase III trial (ACP-103, 2014): 37% improvement in SAPS-PD vs placebo; no motor effect.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Psychosis arises from mesolimbic pathway overactivity (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens) and frontal cortex 5-HT2A receptor dysregulation. Dementia involves degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert projecting to cortex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

α-Synuclein aggregates in cortical and limbic regions disrupt cholinergic and serotonergic circuits, while exogenous dopaminergic therapy further disinhibits mesolimbic dopamine release, precipitating psychosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Clozapine: start low (12.5 mg), slow titration, strict hematologic monitoring due to agranulocytosis risk. Avoid anticholinergics which can worsen cognitive decline.
